review.title: Ranking and significance of variable-length similarity-based time series motifs
review.abstract: The detection of very similar patterns in a time series, commonly called motifs, has received continuous and increasing attention from diverse scientific communities. In particular, recent approaches for discovering similar motifs of different lengths have been proposed. In this work, we show that such variable-length similarity-based motifs cannot be directly compared, and hence ranked, by their normalized dissimilarities. Specifically, we find that length-normalized motif dissimilarities still have intrinsic dependencies on the motif length, and that lowest dissimilarities are particularly affected by this dependency. Moreover, we find that such dependencies are generally non-linear and change with the considered data set and dissimilarity measure. Based on these findings, we propose a solution to rank those motifs and measure their significance. This solution relies on a compact but accurate model of the dissimilarity space, using a beta distribution with three parameters that depend on the motif length in a non-linear way. We believe the incomparability of variable-length dissimilarities could go beyond the field of time series, and that similar modeling strategies as the one used here could be of help in a more broad context.

metadata.title: Ranking and significance of variable-length similarity-based time series motifs

sections.text: Recognition of very similar patterns in a time series commonly referred to as motives has received continuous and increasing attention from various scientific communities. In particular, more recent approaches to the discovery of similar motives of different lengths have been proposed. In this work, we show that such motives based on variable length cannot be directly compared by their normalized differences and can therefore be classified. In particular, we note that length normalized motifs still exhibit intrinsic dependencies on the motif length and that the slightest differences are particularly affected by this dependence. Furthermore, we note that such dependencies are generally non-linear and vary with the data set under consideration and measure dissimilarity. On the basis of these results, we propose a solution to classify these motifs and measure their significance. This solution is based on a compact but precise model of dissimilarity space, using a beta distribution of three parameters depending on the motif length in a non-linear time shift.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The time series typically represents a fundamental dynamics of a time series or a system. When appropriate measurements are made, the information contained in a time series can be crucial to understanding and / or modelling such a system. In particular, the capture of repeated or very similar patterns in a time series commonly referred to as a motif has shown that it can be of great value to researchers and practitioners. Examples range from natural and health sciences to animation or business analysis (Mueen, 2014).Email addresses: jserra @ iiia.csic.es (Joan Serra), iserra @ crm.cat (Isabel Serra), acorral @ crm.cat (A), arcos @ iii.es (Josep Lluis Arcos Arcos Arcos) Preprint, the Elsevier March 9, 2015ar Xiv: 150 3.01 883v 1 [cs.L G] 6M, In general two definitions of a time series, we exist an interesting time series.

sections.heading: 2.2. Quantitative evaluation
sections.text: In order to quantify the incomparability of d with respect to the smaller fluctuations in distribution differences, we need two basic measures of the difference between distributions. First, we look at the global discrepancy between empirical CDFs compared to each other. We quantify them by the total number of probability distributions (Levin et al., 2009), where there is an arbitrary difference between the two empirical CDFs compared to each other. Nevertheless, since we use CDFs and take the average, there is a quick and intuitive idea of the average difference between distributions. The resolution for all the experiments we have reported here corresponds to k = 100 equally graded values between the minimum and maximum values of each sample. Since we are interested in the best motives, we must pay particular attention to the smaller fluctuations in distribution differences.

sections.heading: 3. Modeling motif dissimilarities
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1. Main idea
sections.text: In order to overcome the disadvantages described in the previous section, we now propose a method for modelling the dissimilarity space. Our goal is to build a compact model of the empirical dissimilarity distributions for each W. We want to transform the dissimilarity space into a unified probability space in which motives of different lengths can be compared in a meaningful way. In paragraph 2, we have seen that in the face of two longitudinally normalized dissimilarity di and dj derived from wi and wj, the relationship di < dj does not necessarily mean that dj should be classified by di. Our observation is that by looking at an estimated CDF for each w, we can mix motifs of different lengths and compare them meaningfully.

sections.heading: 3.2. Preliminary analysis
sections.text: An illustration of the empirical probability distribution function (PDFs) for deviations from fixed values is shown in Fig. 7. Note that a Gaussian model might initially appear to be a reasonable model, but this is not the case. Gaussian model is a good model for the central part of an empirical distribution, but it has the caveat that kurtosis is always zero. Therefore, it does not model the observed tails correctly. In contrast, the motive discovery task based on similarity requires accurate estimates of the tails of such distributions. In fact, we are only interested in the smallest existing inequalities. Therefore, our modeling task requires a good model for the tails. In particular, it requires a model with a good fit in the left, lowest distribution limit. Extreme Value Theory (EVT) focuses on the exact modeling of the tail (Beirlant).

sections.heading: 3.3. Model fit
sections.text: The beta distribution typically depends on two form parameters, each corresponding to the tail index of each page (β β = 3). The extreme value for near-zero dissimilarity is zero, but in the case of the maximum we have seen that it depends on the original data sets and therefore we use the three parameters Beta DistributionP (d) = 1mB (α, β) (dm) -1 (1 − dm) β − 1, (1), where there are the so-called form parameters, m is a scale parameter, and B (α, β) is the beta function. Eq. 1 is defined for 0 ≤ d ≤ m. For values outside this range P (d) = 0.We start by adjusting a beta distribution for each w. We do this by applying the maximum probability.

sections.heading: 3.4. Model usage
sections.text: As already mentioned, our final goal is to "normalize" the deviation space with respect to variations in w. To do this, we only need to calculate αw, βw and mw according to Eqs. 3-7 and consider the CDF of the proposed model Pw (D ≤ d) = B (d mw; αw, βw) B (αw, βw), where B (x; α, β) is the incomplete beta function, a generalization of the beta function. The incomplete beta function can be efficiently calculated using functions commonly found in spreadsheet or programming systems (Press et al., 2007). Since Pw (D ≤ d) is defined only for 0 ≤ d ≤ mw, we suggest the new deviation measured ′ = 0 if d < 0Pw (D ≤ d) is equal for the accuracy of this position, if 0 ≤ d is equal for the accuracy (D ≤ d) or the accuracy of other motifs of different lengths under the same conditions.

sections.heading: 3.5. Model validation
sections.text: In order to measure the quality of the model fit Pw, we refer to the measures introduced in paragraph 2.2: the global discrepancy between empirical CDF and pKS, the p-value of the KS test at the lowest quartile of the samples. The only difference is that the pKS value here is not the result of a test with two samples, but the result of a quality test for the plausibility of our proposed model in view of the available samples (we adapt the generative procedure for bootstrap described by Clauset et al. (2009) to the current model. If we calculate all the measured variables and data sets considered and calculate pKS, we see that the inserted models generally provide a good correlation with the data (Fig. 9). In general, the pKS value is never above 0.02 and rarely above 0.01. The pKS value is often above 0.05, indicating that we can reject the zero hypotheses of the swan fit = 0.0002, which is relative to the 0000z = the 0.000z used for Jones.

sections.heading: 4. Materials and methods
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1. Time series data sets
sections.text: To show that our results are not distorted with respect to the data source, we look at 9 different publicly available time series of different lengths originating from different areas: (1) DowJones - the daily closing values of the Dow Jones Industrial Average (Williamson, 2012); (2) CarCount - the number of cars used for the ramp on Highway 101 North in Los Angeles, CA, USA (Ihler et al., 2006); (3) Insect - the electrical penetration curve of a beet leaf hopper 3 (Mueen et al., 2009); (4) EEG - a one-hour electroencephalogram of a single channel in a sleeping patient4 (Mueen et al., 2009); (5) FieldRecording - the spectral centroid of a field (Mueen et al., 2009); (4) EEG - a one-hour electroencephalogram of a single channel in a sleeping patient4 (Mueen et al., 2009); the electroencephalogram of a single channel in a sleeping patient (Mueen et., 2009).

sections.heading: 4.2. Dissimilarity measurement
sections.text: To show that our results are not distorted in terms of measuring similarity, we consider 8 different and commonly used time series differences (see Serra & Arcos, 2014, and references to them): (1) Euc - Euclidean distance normalized by √ w; (2) sqEuc - square Euclidean distance normalized by w; (3) Corr - Persons correlation; (4) Cos - cosine inequality; (5) DTW - dynamic time distortion normalized by path length; and (8) MDL - minimal description length as in Rakthanmanon et al. (2011), with an additional constant to force d versus 0.

sections.heading: 4.3. Motif sampling
sections.text: In view of the formal definition of similarity-based time series motifs (Mueen et al., 2009), we only need to scan the motif space to obtain possible motif candidates. In particular, we take n = 2000 motif samples for each w equally random and avoid explicitly trivial matches (Chiu et al., 2003). That is, at a motif length w we randomly generate the beginning of the segments that form the motif, i, j [1, N − w], where N is the time series length, so that, if not stated otherwise, we look at wmin = 5 and wmax = 500, i.e. w [5, 500].

sections.heading: 4.4. Further results, code, and data availability
sections.text: We will make all raw results, code and data available on our website as soon as possible.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: The main contribution of the current work is to show that time series dissidences of different lengths are not directly comparable and therefore cannot be evaluated. Through both motivational examples and formal quantitative analysis, we have shown (1) that they have the least differences in terms of motif, (2) that these dependencies change with the data and measure the dissidence, and (3) that they have the least differences in terms of interest in similarity to the motif. (3) Another contribution of the current work is a solution to address the evolved problems and measure the dissidence, and (3) that they relate to the least differences in terms of motif.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We would like to thank all those who contributed the data sets used in this study, which were financed by the Generalitat de Catalunya and the Spanish government: 2009-SGR-1434 (JS, JLA), 2014-SGR-1307 (AC, IS), FIS2012-31324 (AC), MTM2012-31118 (IS) and TIN2012-38450-C03-03 (JS, JLA).

referenceMentions.context: Examples range from natural and health sciences to animation or business analytics (Mueen, 2014).
The first one is based on the notion of frequency (Lin et al., 2002): a pattern is interesting if it has a significant amount of repetitions.
The second one is based on the notion of similarity (Mueen et al., 2009): a pattern is interesting if its occurrences are identical or too similar to happen at random.

Hence, algorithms exploiting both notions independently have received continuous and increasing attention (Chiu et al., 2003; Tanaka et al., 2005; Mueen et al., 2009; Tang & Liao, 2008; Rakthanmanon et al., 2011; Mueen, 2013; Yingchareonthawornchai et al., 2013).

Hence, algorithms exploiting both notions independently have received continuous and increasing attention (Chiu et al., 2003; Tanaka et al., 2005; Mueen et al., 2009; Tang & Liao, 2008; Rakthanmanon et al., 2011; Mueen, 2013; Yingchareonthawornchai et al., 2013).

Hence, algorithms exploiting both notions independently have received continuous and increasing attention (Chiu et al., 2003; Tanaka et al., 2005; Mueen et al., 2009; Tang & Liao, 2008; Rakthanmanon et al., 2011; Mueen, 2013; Yingchareonthawornchai et al., 2013).

Hence, algorithms exploiting both notions independently have received continuous and increasing attention (Chiu et al., 2003; Tanaka et al., 2005; Mueen et al., 2009; Tang & Liao, 2008; Rakthanmanon et al., 2011; Mueen, 2013; Yingchareonthawornchai et al., 2013).

Hence, algorithms exploiting both notions independently have received continuous and increasing attention (Chiu et al., 2003; Tanaka et al., 2005; Mueen et al., 2009; Tang & Liao, 2008; Rakthanmanon et al., 2011; Mueen, 2013; Yingchareonthawornchai et al., 2013). Under a frequency-based definition, the ranking of the motifs found in a time series is trivial. The most important motif is the one with the highest count, the second most important motif is the one with the second highest count, and so on. Moreover, we can assess the statistical significance of frequency-based motifs by comparing observed and expected counts under a null model reflecting some basic characteristics of the time series. This has been exploited by Castro & Azevedo (2011), who leverage work from the bioinformatics community to derive a motif’s significance.
Specifically, we consider the well-known KolmogorovSmirnov (KS) test (Massey, 1951) and its associated p-value, which we denote by pKS.
This is interesting, as in economics the random walk hypothesis has been used to model share prices and other factors for a long time (Malkiel, 1973).
In any case, using models for tails requires the existence of an optimal threshold defining the starting point of the tail (Coles, 2001).
To do so, we choose a particle swarm optimizer (Poli et al., 2007).
We here use the canonical PSO algorithm (Poli et al., 2007), with 25 particles and a local best configuration, and run 300 iterations.
The incomplete beta function can be efficiently calculated using functions that are commonly included in spreadsheet or programming systems (Press et al., 2007).

difference is that here the pKS value is not the result of a two-sample test, but the result of a goodness of fit test for the plausibility of our proposed model given the available samples (we adapt the bootstrap generative procedure described by Clauset et al. (2009) for power-law models to the current model).

Time series data sets To demonstrate that our results are not biased with regard to the data source, we consider 9 different publicly-available time series of varying length, coming from distinct domains: (1) DowJones – the daily closing values of the Dow Jones industrial average (Williamson, 2012); (2) CarCount – the number of cars measured for the Glendale on ramp for the 101 North freeway in Los Angeles, CA, USA (Ihler et al.

Time series data sets To demonstrate that our results are not biased with regard to the data source, we consider 9 different publicly-available time series of varying length, coming from distinct domains: (1) DowJones – the daily closing values of the Dow Jones industrial average (Williamson, 2012); (2) CarCount – the number of cars measured for the Glendale on ramp for the 101 North freeway in Los Angeles, CA, USA (Ihler et al., 2006); (3) Insect – the electrical penetration graph of a beet leafhopper (Mueen et al.
, 2006); (3) Insect – the electrical penetration graph of a beet leafhopper (Mueen et al., 2009); (4) EEG – a one hour electroencephalogram from a single channel in a sleeping patient (Mueen et al.

, 2009); (4) EEG – a one hour electroencephalogram from a single channel in a sleeping patient (Mueen et al., 2009); (5) FieldRecording – the spectral centroid of a field recording (we used the mean of the stereo channels and the spectral centroid linear frequency plugin from Sonic Visualizer); (6) Wind – the wind speed registered in the buoy of Rincon del San Jose, TX, USA.

(7) Power – the electric power consumption of an individual household (Bache & Lichman, 2013); (8) EOG – an electrooculogram tracking the eye movements of a sleeping patient (Goldberger et al., 2000); and (9) RandomWalk – a random walk time series, artificially generated using zi+1 = zi+η and z1 = 0, where η is a Gaussian random number with zero mean and unit variance.

Dissimilarity measurement To demonstrate that our results are not biased with regard to the similarity measurement, we consider 8 different and commonly-used time series dissimilarity measures (see Serrà & Arcos, 2014, and references therein): (1) Euc – Euclidean distance normalized by √ w; (2) sqEuc – squared Euclidean distance normalized by w; (3) Corr – Pearson’s correlation, (4) Cos – cosine dissimilarity, (5) DTW – dynamic time warping with path-accumulated normalization weights and a ±5% corridor window; (6) EDR – edit distance with real penalty normalized by the path length; (7) TWED – time-warped edit distance normalized by the path length; and (8) MDL – minimum description length as in Rakthanmanon et al. (2011), with an added constant to force d ≥ 0.
Motif sampling Given the formal definition of similarity-based time series motifs (Mueen et al., 2009), to obtain possible motif candidates we just need to sample the motif space.
In particular, we take n = 2000 motif samples for each w uniformly at random, and explicitly avoid trivial matches (Chiu et al., 2003).

This assumption is well motivated, as practically all existing motif discovery algorithms operate under such constraint (e.g., Lin et al., 2002; Chiu et al., 2003; Tanaka et al., 2005; Mueen et al., 2009; Castro & Azevedo, 2011; Mueen, 2013; Yingchareonthawornchai et al., 2013).

metadata.abstractText: The detection of very similar patterns in a time series, commonly called motifs, has received continuous and increasing attention from diverse scientific communities. In particular, recent approaches for discovering similar motifs of different lengths have been proposed. In this work, we show that such variable-length similarity-based motifs cannot be directly compared, and hence ranked, by their normalized dissimilarities. Specifically, we find that length-normalized motif dissimilarities still have intrinsic dependencies on the motif length, and that lowest dissimilarities are particularly affected by this dependency. Moreover, we find that such dependencies are generally non-linear and change with the considered data set and dissimilarity measure. Based on these findings, we propose a solution to rank those motifs and measure their significance. This solution relies on a compact but accurate model of the dissimilarity space, using a beta distribution with three parameters that depend on the motif length in a non-linear way. We believe the incomparability of variable-length dissimilarities could go beyond the field of time series, and that similar modeling strategies as the one used here could be of help in a more broad context.
